ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course. I was interested in the period coming in, but I think that even had I not been, the subject matter was rich and broad enough and the teaching engrossing enough that I would have enjoyed the class regardless.

Appropriately paced; reading list provides comprehensive survey of criticism to assist study of the poems; writingassignments consist of informal protocol presentations (based on 4-5 p. written responses to the poems) and a final research paper (with a brief progress report to the class). A 20-minute presentation on a topic of choice was also required. I have thoroughly enjoyed this class - it has deepened my appreciation (and comprehension) of Middle English and manuscript culture, introduced me to the working group/presentation format, facilitated my use and understanding of criticism, and allowed me to study some of the most complex and enjoyable works (poems of Cotton Nero, St. Erkenwald) I have ever read.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I am an undergraduate with no prior exposure to medieval literature. This course has deepened my appreciation (and comprehension) of Middle English and manuscript culture, introduced me to the working group/presentation format, facilitated my use and understanding of criticism, and allowed me to study some of the most complex and enjoyable works (poems of Cotton Nero, St. Erkenwald) I have ever read. I am very glad to have taken this class.
